original_solution_mapping.L1: Thomas originally orders chairs for 3 dozen guests, 12 x 3 = 36 guests
original_solution_mapping.L2: Thomas finds out that 1/3 of the guests want to bring a guest of their own, 1/3 of 36 = <<1/3*36=12>>12
original_solution_mapping.L3: The 12 guests bring a guest of their own each, 36 guests + 12 guests = <<36+12=48>>48
original_solution_mapping.L4: Thomas finds out that 20 of the guests can't make it, 48 guests - 5 guests = 43
original_solution_mapping.L5: Thomas wants to order an extra 12 chairs, 43 + 12 = <<43+12=55>>55
original_solution_mapping.L6: Thomas will need 55 chairs for the party.

original_function_code:
def solve():
    """Index: 6566.
    Returns: the total number of chairs Thomas will order.
    """
    # L1
    initial_dozens_guests = 3 # 3 dozen guests he invites
    chairs_per_dozen = 12 # WK
    initial_guests = chairs_per_dozen * initial_dozens_guests

    # L2
    fraction_guests_bring_guest = Fraction(1, 3) # 1/3 of the guests want to bring a guest of their own
    guests_bringing_guests = fraction_guests_bring_guest * initial_guests

    # L3
    total_guests_after_additions = initial_guests + guests_bringing_guests

    # L4
    guests_cant_make_it = 5 # 5 of the guests he originally invited can't make it
    guests_after_cancellations = total_guests_after_additions - guests_cant_make_it

    # L5
    extra_chairs = 12 # 12 extra chairs
    final_chairs_needed = guests_after_cancellations + extra_chairs

    # FA
    answer = final_chairs_needed
    return answer

logical_steps.solution_line_template: Thomas originally orders chairs for {initial_dozens_guests} dozen guests, {chairs_per_dozen} x {initial_dozens_guests} = {initial_guests} guests

Thomas finds out that {fraction_guests_bring_guest} of the guests want to bring a guest of their own, {fraction_guests_bring_guest} of {initial_guests} = <<{fraction_guests_bring_guest}*{initial_guests}={guests_bringing_guests}>>{guests_bringing_guests}

The {guests_bringing_guests} guests bring a guest of their own each, {initial_guests} guests + {guests_bringing_guests} guests = <<{initial_guests}+{guests_bringing_guests}={total_guests_after_additions}>>{total_guests_after_additions}
Thomas finds out that 20 of the guests can't make it, {total_guests_after_additions} guests - {guests_cant_make_it} guests = {guests_after_cancellations}
Thomas wants to order an extra {extra_chairs} chairs, {guests_after_cancellations} + {extra_chairs} = <<{guests_after_cancellations}+{extra_chairs}={final_chairs_needed}>>{final_chairs_needed}

flawed_nl_reconstruction.L1: Thomas originally orders chairs for 3 dozen guests, 12 x 3 = 36 guests
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L2: Thomas finds out that 1/3 of the guests want to bring a guest of their own, 1/3 of 36 = <<1/3*36=12>>12
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L3: The 12 guests bring a guest of their own each, 36 guests + 12 guests = <<36+12=48>>48
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L4: Thomas finds out that 20 of the guests can't make it, 12 guests - 5 guests = 7
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L5: Thomas wants to order an extra 12 chairs, 7 + 12 = <<7+12=19>>19

explanation: Incorrect operand. The variable 'chairs_per_dozen' (value: 12) was used instead of 'total_guests_after_additions' (value: 48).
